docs.lead_paragraph: The Parenting Group Inc., a subsidiary of Time Warner's Time Inc., announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement with Hachette Filipacchi magazines, a unit of Lagardere Group, to purchase Family Life magazine. Time Inc.'s Parenting Group already owns Healthy Pregnancy, Baby Talk and Parenting magazines, as well as First Moments, a distribution company that is targeted at newly married couples and expectant and new parents. Parenting magazine has a circulation of 1.25 million. Its chief competitor, Parents, which is published by Bertelsmann's Gruner & Jahr U.S.A. unit, has a circulation of 1.7 million.

headline.main: Time Inc. Unit to Buy Family Life Magazine

docs.abstract: Parenting Group Inc, subsidiary of Time Warner's Time Inc, reaches agreement with Hachette Filipacchi magazines, unit of Lagardere Group, to purchase Family Life magazine (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: David Mann has played piano and written arrangements for Frank Sinatra, serenaded President Truman on his yacht and written popular music like the song ''In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning.'' More recently, from his home in Kinnelon, N.J., he sits at a different keyboard, talking about classical music with the members of a chat room on America Online. By his estimate, he puts in at least five hours a week as a volunteer, moderating a weekly chat session, answering E-mail and filling out an on-line report about his duties.

headline.main: Despite a Passion for the Net, Many On-Line Volunteers Want Pay

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I FEEL testosterone surging through my veins,'' said Susan Sistrom, a doll-size woman engulfed in a swelling pool of portly men at Sparks Steak House in midtown on Wednesday night. ''I feel like the Yankees are going to show up,'' said Patricia Marx, also a pretty, tiny person.

headline.main: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Skinny Women; Thin in a Den of Fat

docs.abstract: Group of extremely slender New York women dine out amidst portly men at Sparks Steak House, and discuss how delighted they are to be thin; photo; Susan Sistrom and Patricia Marx, authors of book The Skinny, advise eating less, even if that means Diet Cokes and cigarettes for first ten hours of the day (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Mount Sinai Medical Center illegally discriminated against the deaf husband of a pregnant woman by refusing to provide a sign language interpreter while the couple were attending Lamaze classes, a Federal judge has ruled. As a result of the hospital's refusal, Jeffrey Bravin, a teacher at the Lexington School for the Deaf in Manhattan, was unable to learn the Lamaze method of assisting a woman giving birth, Judge Robert W. Sweet of Federal District Court in Manhattan said in his opinion on Wednesday. Mr. Bravin's wife, Naomi, needed a birthing partner to take part in the classes and to learn the techniques being taught, the judge wrote.

headline.main: Judge Finds Bias at Hospital In Dealings With Deaf Man

docs.abstract: Federal court rules that Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York discriminated against deaf husband of pregnant woman by not providing sign language interpreter while couple attended Lamaze classes; Judge Robert W Sweet also notes that hospital did not provide interpreters for Jeffrey and Naomi Bravin during birth or week after, when their son was in neonatal intensive care unit (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Responding to reports that inmates recovering from childbirth have been routinely kept in shackles, the New York City Department of Correction said yesterday that it had changed its procedures so that prison officials can more quickly determine whether restraints are necessary. Under the new policy, paperwork indicating whether a pregnant inmate is a potential security risk will be sent along when the inmate is transferred from Rikers Island to Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens, where all pregnant inmates are taken for childbirth, said the city's Correction Commissioner, Bernard B. Kerik.

headline.main: Restraint Policy Changed For Pregnant Inmates

docs.abstract: New York City Corrections Dept, responding to reports that inmates recovering from childbirth have been routinely kept in shackles, changes its procedures so that prison officials can more quickly determine whether restraints are necessary (S)
